docs.lead_paragraph: When the Urban Institute was founded here 18 years ago, probably no one envisioned that it would become a major research organization, evaluating every aspect of national domestic affairs from taxes to the performance of Presidents. The Johnson Administration, concerned about riots and disintegration of the cities, established the institute because of a sense that not enough was known about either municipal problems or the Federal programs designed to cure them. In time, the institute's main work turned out to be scholarly studies evaluating a whole raft of problems and programs that continued long after the cities had cooled off, after the public had lost interest in urban affairs and after the subject had become something of a stepchild of Republican and Democratic administrations alike. Most recently, the institute's Changing Domestic Priorities project has shown anew how nimble its officials are at spotting areas in which research is needed and would strike a responsive cord.

headline.main: The Urban Institute, Then and Now
